thread.title: Vikings rack up the points while handing Walburn 100th coaching win
thread.title_full: Vikings rack up the points while handing Walburn 100th coaching win

title: Vikings rack up the points while handing Walburn 100th coaching win
text:
Vikings rack up the points while handing Walburn 100th coaching win by Comments 
Northgate head coach Tommy Walburn is congratulated on his 100th win by former school principal Dr. Therese Reddekopp on Homecoming night. 
On a night where head coach Tommy Walburn celebrated his 100th career victory, Northgate nearly racked up a point for every one of them against Forest Park. 
The Vikings continued an undefeated season with their biggest offensive output of the year while their defense came up with the third shutout this fall in a 68-0 Homecoming victory. 
With the win, Northgate remains unbeaten heading into Thursday’s game at Drew. 
“We were able to get a big lead earlier and play a lot of different people, and that is always good,” Walburn said. 
Now at 7-0 and 4-0 in Region 4A- , the schedule gets tougher from here on out, starting with the Titans next week. Also ahead is a showdown with Starr’s Mill when the two teams play for the No. 1 seed in the subregion in two weeks. Friday’s win was the Vikings’ third shutout of the season, with Northgate having now outscored opponents by a 275-20 margin in 2015. 
After Friday’s victory against Forest Park, the school presented Walburn with a banner commemorating the coaching milestone, a milestone that included coaching stints at Troup County and Crisp County starting in 2001. 
“It’s exciting, but I never scored a touchdown or made a tackle,” Walburn said. “I have been surrounded by great coaches and players. It has always been a team effort.” 
Walburn’s 38th win Friday at Northgate was arguably the most dominant in school history, with the Vikings building a 62-0 lead even before this year’s Homecoming queen was crowned at the school. The second half was played under a running clock against the Panthers, who fell to 0-7 and suffered the program’s 18th consecutive loss. 
Northgate needed just four plays to build a 21-0 lead over the Panthers and after a 45-minute first quarter the Vikings extended the margin to 37-0. 
Fullback Kyle Cater scored on touchdown runs of two, seven and 37 yards to help pace the offense. 
His first two scores game just two minutes apart early in the first quarter. 
Ton Evans found the end zone twice, scoring on touchdowns of 10 and 17 yards. 
Kamari Ray also found the end zone on a two-yard run and Nick Carter scored on a one-yard scamper to close out the first-half scoring. 
Trandon Torres-Niles found the end zone on a one-yard scamper for the Vikings’ only touchdown in the second half. 
The Vikings’ defense flexed their muscles Friday, adding three safeties before halftime. 
Senior linebacker James Skalski tackled the Forest Park quarterback in the end zone for one of the safeties. He also recovered a fumble in the end zone for a touchdown. 
A botched snap that sailed over the Forest Park punter’s head rolled out of the end zone for the other safety. 
Northgate took advantage of good field possession the entire night. All but one of the Vikings’ first-half drives started in Forest Park territory. 
The Panthers had trouble getting its personnel on the field and was called for five illegal substitution penalties in the first quarter. 
Forest Park, the school that produced University of Georgia All-American and Pittsburgh Steelers All Pro Hines Ward, has lost 18 straight games and hasn’t had a winning season since 2000, when it finished 7-3 but missed the playoffs. 
The Panthers’ last postseason campaign was in 1996. More
